keyTakeAways: Richard Kenneth Djerf was executed in Arizona for the 1993 murder of four members of the Luna family, including two minors, in a revenge-driven act stemming from a prior theft.
The execution was Arizona’s second of the year and the 39th execution in 2025, highlighting the ongoing use of capital punishment despite past controversies.
The execution took about 10 minutes to complete, with Djerf's veins being suboptimal, indicating technical challenges in the lethal injection process.
Arizona has faced criticism for past botched executions, including a 2014 case where a prisoner received 15 doses of drugs over two hours, leading to prolonged suffering and public outcry.
The state paused executions twice since 2014 due to concerns over the process and drug access, with a formal review ending in November 2024 and new protocols introduced.
Djerf admitted responsibility in a prior statement and expressed remorse, showing a rare moment of accountability from a death row inmate.
No victims’ family members were present during the execution, raising questions about closure and public mourning for the victims.
The execution is part of a national pattern, with five more executions scheduled this year across the U.S., including in Florida, Alabama, Oklahoma, and Tennessee.
With this execution, Arizona now has 107 prisoners on death row, indicating a significant and growing death row population.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Richard Kenneth Djerf, 55, was executed in Arizona on October 18, 2025, for the 1993 murder of four members of the Luna family in Phoenix—Albert Luna Sr., Patricia Luna, Rochelle Luna, and Damien Luna—after a revenge plot triggered by a prior theft. Prosecutors claim Djerf targeted the family after blaming Albert Luna Jr. for a stolen item, leading to a violent attack in which he sexually assaulted Rochelle, killed Albert Sr. with a bat and gunfire, and murdered the others by binding and shooting them. Djerf declined to make a final statement and was executed via lethal injection, a process that took about 10 minutes despite technical difficulties with IV placement. The execution was Arizona’s second of the year and the 39th of 2025, marking a continuation of capital punishment after previous pauses due to public criticism, drug access issues, and botched executions, such as that of Joseph Wood in 2014. The state’s death row now has 107 inmates, and the case reflects broader debates over the ethics, efficacy, and humane execution of the death penalty in the United States.
title: Arizona Executes Man for Killing 4 Members of a Family in Phoenix in 1993
